reviewText: Ranchers must take their cattle to market via a trail that leads to the Hollow mountain. Surrounded by swamps, the mountain is allegedly cursed. The first two thirds of the film is taken up by the rancher's (Guy Mitchell) love for a village girl. She's engaged to be married to another man, leading to jealousy, fights, and the groom-to-be's plot to cause a stampede! Meanwhile, THE BEAST OF HOLLOW MOUNTAIN eats one of the rancher's hired hands. Then, we're taken back to town for the big wedding celebration. Suddenly, the BEAST strikes, causing a stampede of its own! The creature is shown in two ways, either as a pair of rubber monster feet walking by, or as a stop-motion T-REX-type dinosaur lumbering along. Alas, the BEAST has little screen time. Still, the characters are endearing enough to make things bearable. Don't expect a lot of monster action. This is more of a western / drama which just happens to have a dinosaur in it. The finale is worth waiting for, as we get to (finally) see the BEAST on a destructive rampage. I enjoyed it, but I'll take monsters any way I can get them!...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Fans of giant monster movies from the 50's and 60's will be pleased to know that The Beast of Hollow Mountain has found it's way to an official U.S. Blu Ray release. The film is paired with another old monster on the loose film The Neanderthal Man. Both films look very good on their debut(factory pressed)release to digital format and for the most part are entertaining at least to those who grew up watching them.The Beast of Hollow Mountain is one of my fondness memories from back in the days of Saturday morning creature features. It has a good monster though only seen late in the film, he delivers the goods and the film has a very memorable ending. It stuck with me for years. The stop motion effects aren't O'Brien or Harryhausen quality, but the monster is pretty cool looking non the less.
summary: NOW AVAILABLE ON BLU RAY ON A DOUBLE BILL! CLASSIC CREATURE FEATURE!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay.  I understand why some would decide this movie bites.  To an extent it does have a major flaw.  The "Beast" only shows up towards the end.  Be that as it may.  Yet, for my generation, this movie presents cinematic technology at its finest.  The part where the "beast" corners the heroine and child in that shack, makes me wonder if the tyrannosaur devoured the previous inhabitants.  It is a movie where one should not read into it, rather enjoy it based on its cinematic achievements and state of the art technology then available.  While I agree it is pricey, it is worth viewing the technology of Willis Obrien that paved the way for Ray Harryhausen and Steven Spielberg.  Kick back, let your imagination run wild and enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: People who have panned this movie forget a few things.  For many, many years, this showed up on TV, but ONLY IN A FULL SCREEN, bad image quality print.  I don't even remember where I got it, but I thankfully found a nice widescreen 2:35 print of the film, and have always treasured it, because it was the forerunner to other western dinosaur movies, like VALLEY OF GUANGI, THE LOST DINOSAUR, and others.  I think Harryhausen was inspired by Hollow Mountain, and paid homage to Willis O'brien in the making of GUANGI. I couldn't disagree more about the dinosaur in HOLLOW MOUNTAIN.  With the vibrant color of the widescreen print, I'll never forget that wagging red tongue! The movie is slow, but we have to remember that I'm sure O'brien was also frustrated by the second billing his dinosaur got next to Patricia Medina and Guy Madison's on and off romance, which is a yawner.  I recommend this disc based on other reviews, and because it may be the only chance to ever see this movie the way it was originally presented.  If this PAL is the only way to see it, EVER, I also recommend those who purchase it, KEEP IT, because it may go out of print, making it very valuable.

reviewText: It is 1956. Neither replacement animation, color or widescreen will prevent this film from becoming a dim baby boomer memory. The indignity will only deepen with age as complaints of slowness and boredom settle in with younger viewers.The camera booms down into the graveyard following Guy Madison. Your expectations come to nothing when he only meets Patricia Medina. This mysterious and expectant camera movement is never far away during fights or other action sequences. But they don't seem to coalesce into meaningful conclusions.Flash forward to TORN CURTAIN as Paul Newman and Julie Andrews are running from gunmen. They escape into the back seat of a car and duck down as you expect the rear windshield to be blasted out but slowly sit up as they realize nothing has happened. But of course this was Hitchcock, a genius who knew all about suspense!UPDATE: Thank you Scream Factory in early 2014. My future is Blu!!!

reviewText: I have been after this movie for a long time as I had never seen it and was keen to. The price asked by the seller was huge not only was it in US dollars but the cost of post made it around $50 Australian even with the Aussie dollar high. I did find it however for Ten dollars Australiand post paid so sent money what I got was a clear crisp wide screen (started off letterboxed for the titles) Guy Madison is a favourite of mine and have a great deal of his work. The story is set around a mountain that legend has it has some sort of monster living in it. For some reason the making of the film sets off the monster on a rampage of killing cattle. Guy and his partner who own a ranch of course are in the way of another evil rancher who wants their ranch (sounds familiar) he of course is engaged to a lovely senorita (again where have I seen that before) wont spoil this to much for you If you can find a $10 copy  buy it just as a matter of intrest the monster makes no appearance untill almost half way through the movie If you have seen Harrys pecial effect stop  animation you know what to expect but it is fun and the kids will look at you in wonderment as to why the heck you are watching it and think????? ?thats if you decide to share it with them.Al Watts presenter of Big Als Rhythm Rounduo pbs 106.7
